context_packet_father_pattern.snippet: # Personal Suffering Narrative (Acute) — Draft 1 ## 1) Marriage / Life-Building → Coerced Separation → Narrative Rewriting You built a real, functional life and trajectory with your ex-wife for years. Then you were relentlessly pressured (especially by your father) to leave her. After you did, the entire reality was rewritten: instead of recognizing the years of effort and the coercive pressure, it was reframed as you “failing,” being morally implicated, and needing to be “rescued.” So a long period of competence and stability became retroactively converted into a story of defect and collapse—despite the fact you had been building and sustaining something real. ## 2) 20+ Years of Religious Striving → Collapse of the Framework For over two decades you strived relentlessly to know God—leading Bible studies, studying continuously, doing everything you could to “get relief” and spiritual sec

context_packet_father_pattern.snippet: One specific destabilizer has been my father interpreting physical distance as rejection, which triggers rumination, ego injury, and eventual escalation. ## Key Insight Occasional shared, low-engagement activities (e.g., watching TV together) function as signal management, not emotional connection. This behavior is not about closeness, bonding, or authenticity. It is about reducing perceived threat and preventing destabilization.

context_packet_father_pattern.snippet: ## Note: Control-by-Denial / Proxy-Stability Dynamic (Mechanism-Level) What I am observing is not confusion, forgetfulness, or inconsistency. It is a self-regulating control dynamic. ### Key characteristics - My mother has repeatedly acknowledged that I am doing what I am supposed to do. - Her baseline verbal stance is often: “Just keep doing what you’re doing.” - However, when acknowledgment would require action, protection, or challenging my father, she withdraws or neutralizes.

context_packet_father_pattern.snippet: Note: Why My Mother Appears to Care My mother’s expressions of care are primarily role-based and self-regulatory, not need-based. She acts caring when: It aligns with her self-image as a “good, compassionate person” It maintains household equilibrium It avoids conflict or emotional discomfort It does not require confronting my father or risking her own stability She withdraws or disengages when: My needs require sustained protection or advocacy Caring would involve discomfort, confrontation, or moral cost A clear choice must be made between my well-being and her emotional safety This indicates that her care is conditional and situational, rooted in duty, identity, and avoidance — not in prioritizing my internal state or survival when it matters most.
